column2: It was late that night when Miss Mapp felt that she was physically incapable of tacking on a single poppy more to the edge of her skirt, and went to the window of the garden-room where she had been working, to close it.

column2: She glanced up at the top story of her own house, and saw that the lights in the servants' rooms were out: she glanced to the right and concluded that her gardener had gone to bed: finally, she glanced down the street and saw with a pang of pleasure that the windows of the Major's house showed no sign of midnight labour.

column2: She took her poppy-bordered skirt over her arm, and smiled her thankful way to bed.

column2: She could allow herself to wonder with a little more definiteness, now that the Major's lights were out and he was abed, what it could be which rendered Captain Puffin so oblivious to the passage of time, when he was investigating Roman roads.

column2: How glad she was that the Major was not with him. . . . "Benjamin Flint!" she said to herself as, having put her window open, she trod softly (so as not to disturb the slumberer next door) across her room on her fat white feet to her big white bed. "Good night, Major Benjy," she whispered, as she put her light out.

column2: It was not to be supposed that Diva would act on Miss Mapp's alarming hints that morning as to the fate of coal-hoarders, and give, say, a ton of fuel to the hospital at once, in lieu of her usual smaller Christmas contribution, without making further inquiries in the proper quarters as to the legal liabilities of having, so she ascertained, three tons in her cellar, and as soon as her visitor had left her this morning, she popped out to see Mr. Wootten, her coal-merchant.
column3: It was not to be supposed that Diva would act on Miss Mapp's alarming hints that morning as to the fate of coal hoarders, and give, say, a ton of fuel to the hospital at once, in lieu of her usual smaller Christmas contribution, without making further inquiries in the proper quarters as to the legal liabilities of having, so she ascertained, three tons in her cellar, and as soon as her visitor had left her this morning, she popped out to see mr Wootten, her coal merchant.

column2: She returned in a state of fury, for there were no regulations whatever in existence with regard to the amount of coal that any householder might choose to amass, and Mr. Wootten complimented her on her prudence in having got in a reasonable supply, for he thought it quite probable that, if the coal strike took place, there would be some difficulty in a month's time from now in replenishing cellars.

column3: Then there was the big cupboard under the stairs, but that could scarcely be the site of this prodigious cache, for it was full of cardboard and curtains and carpets and all the rubbishy accumulations which Elizabeth could not bear to part with.

column2: Then she had large cupboards in her bedroom and spare rooms full to overflowing of mouldy clothes, but there was positively not another cupboard in the house that Diva knew of, and she crushed her temples in her hands in the attempt to locate the hiding-place of the hoard.
column3: Then she had large cupboards in her bedroom and spare rooms full to overflowing of mouldy clothes, but there was positively not another cupboard in the house that Diva knew of, and she crushed her temples in her hands in the attempt to locate the hiding place of the hoard.

column2: Diva suddenly jumped up with a happy squeal of discovery, and in her excitement snapped her scissors with so random a stroke that she completely cut in half the bunch of roses that she was engaged on.
column3: Diva suddenly jumped up with a happy squeal of discovery, and in her excitement snapped her scissors with so random a stroke that she completely cut in half the bunch of roses that she was engaged on.

column2: There was another cupboard, the best and biggest of all and the most secret and the most discreet.
column3: There was another cupboard, the best and biggest of all and the most secret and the most discreet.

column2: It lay embedded in the wall of the garden-room, cloaked and concealed behind the shelves of a false book-case, which contained no more than the simulacra of books, just books with titles that had never yet appeared on any honest book.
column3: It lay embedded in the wall of the garden room, cloaked and concealed behind the shelves of a false book case, which contained no more than the simulacra of books, just books with titles that had never yet appeared on any honest book.

column2: There were twelve volumes of "The Beauties of Nature", a shelf full of "Elegant Extracts", there were volumes simply called "Poems", there were "Commentaries", there were "Travels" and "Astronomy" and the lowest and tallest shelf was full of "Music".
column3: There were twelve volumes of "The Beauties of Nature", a shelf full of "Elegant Extracts", there were volumes simply called "Poems", there were "Commentaries", there were "Travels" and "Astronomy" and the lowest and tallest shelf was full of "Music".

column2: A card-table habitually stood in front of this false repository of learning, and it was only last week that Diva, prying casually round the room while Elizabeth had gone to take off her gardening-gloves, had noticed a modest catch let into the woodwork. column3: She would see about that now, for, busy though she was, she could not miss the shopping parade.

column2: Would Diva, she wondered, be at her window, snipping roses out of chintz curtains?
column3: Would Diva, she wondered, be at her window, snipping roses out of chintz curtains?

column2: The careful, thrifty soul. Perhaps this time to-morrow, Diva, looking out of her window, would see that somebody else had been quicker about being thrifty than she.
column3: The careful, thrifty soul. Perhaps this time to morrow, Diva, looking out of her window, would see that somebody else had been quicker about being thrifty than she.

column2: That would be fun!
column3: That would be fun!

column2: The Major's dining-room window was open, and as Miss Mapp passed it, she could not help hearing loud, angry remarks about eggs coming from inside.
column3: The Major's dining room window was open, and as Miss Mapp passed it, she could not help hearing loud, angry remarks about eggs coming from inside.

column2: That made it clear that he was still at breakfast, and that if he had been working at his diaries in the fresh morning hours and forgetting the time, early rising, in spite of his early retirement last night, could not be supposed to suit his Oriental temper.
column3: That made it clear that he was still at breakfast, and that if he had been working at his diaries in the fresh morning hours and forgetting the time, early rising, in spite of his early retirement last night, could not be supposed to suit his Oriental temper.

column2: But a change of habits was invariably known to be upsetting, and Miss Mapp was hopeful that in a day or two he would feel quite a different man.
column3: But a change of habits was invariably known to be upsetting, and Miss Mapp was hopeful that in a day or two he would feel quite a different man.

column2: Farther down the street was quaint Irene lounging at the door of her new studio (a converted coach-house), smoking a cigarette and dressed like a jockey.
column3: Farther down the street was quaint Irene lounging at the door of her new studio (a converted coach house), smoking a cigarette and dressed like a jockey.

column2: Hullo, Mapp, she said.
column3: Hullo, Mapp, she said.

column2: Come and have a look round my new studio.	Come and have a look round my new studio.
column3: true

column2: You haven't seen it yet.
column3: You haven't seen it yet.

column2: I shall give a house-warming next week.
column3: I shall give a house warming next week.

column2: Bridge-party!"
column3: Bridge party!"

column2: Miss Mapp tried to steel herself for the hundredth time to appear quite unconscious that she was being addressed when Irene said "Mapp" in that odious manner.
column3: Miss Mapp tried to steel herself for the hundredth time to appear quite unconscious that she was being addressed when Irene said "Mapp" in that odious manner.

column2: But she never could summon up sufficient nerve to be rude to so awful a mimic. . . .
column3: But she never could summon up sufficient nerve to be rude to so awful a mimic. . . .

column2: Good morning, dear one, she said sycophantically.
column3: Good morning, dear one, she said sycophantically.

column2: Shall I peep in for a moment?
column3: Shall I peep in for a moment?

column2: The decoration of the studio was even more appalling than might have been expected.
column3: The decoration of the studio was even more appalling than might have been expected.

column2: There was a German stove in the corner made of pink porcelain, the rafters and roof were painted scarlet, the walls were of magenta distemper and the floor was blue.
column3: There was a German stove in the corner made of pink porcelain, the rafters and roof were painted scarlet, the walls were of magenta distemper and the floor was blue.

column2: In the corner was a very large orange-coloured screen.
column3: In the corner was a very large orange coloured screen.

column2: The walls were hung with specimens of Irene's art, there was a stout female with no clothes on at all, whom it was impossible not to recognize as being Lucy; there were studies of fat legs and ample bosoms, and on the easel was a picture, evidently in process of completion, which represented a man.
column3: The walls were hung with specimens of Irene's art, there was a stout female with no clothes on at all, whom it was impossible not to recognize as being Lucy; there were studies of fat legs and ample bosoms, and on the easel was a picture, evidently in process of completion, which represented a man.

column2: From this Miss Mapp instantly averted her eyes.
column3: From this Miss Mapp instantly averted her eyes.

column2: Eve, said Irene, pointing to Lucy.
column3: Eve, said Irene, pointing to Lucy.

column2: Miss Mapp naturally guessed that the gentleman who was almost in the same costume was Adam, and turned completely away from him.
column3: Miss Mapp naturally guessed that the gentleman who was almost in the same costume was Adam, and turned completely away from him.

column2: And what a lovely idea to have a blue floor, dear, she said. "How original you are.
column3: And what a lovely idea to have a blue floor, dear, she said. "How original you are.

column2: And that pretty scarlet ceiling.
column3: And that pretty scarlet ceiling.

column2: But don't you find when you're painting that all these bright colours disturb you?"
column3: But don't you find when you're painting that all these bright colours disturb you?"

column2: Not a bit: they stimulate your sense of colour.
column3: Not a bit: they stimulate your sense of colour.

column2: Miss Mapp moved towards the screen.
column3: Miss Mapp moved towards the screen.

column2: What a delicious big screen, she said.
column3: What a delicious big screen, she said.

column2: Yes, but don't go behind it, Mapp, said Irene, "or you'll see my model undressing."
column3: Yes, but don't go behind it, Mapp, said Irene, "or you'll see my model undressing."

column2: Miss Mapp retreated from it precipitately, as from a wasp's nest, and examined some of the studies on the wall, for it was more than probable from the unfinished picture on the easel that Adam lurked behind the delicious screen.
column3: Miss Mapp retreated from it precipitately, as from a wasp's nest, and examined some of the studies on the wall, for it was more than probable from the unfinished picture on the easel that Adam lurked behind the delicious screen.

column2: Terrible though it all was, she was conscious of an unbridled curiosity to know who Adam was.
column3: Terrible though it all was, she was conscious of an unbridled curiosity to know who Adam was.

column2: It was dreadful to think that there could be any man in Tilling so depraved as to stand to be looked at with so little on. . . .
column3: It was dreadful to think that there could be any man in Tilling so depraved as to stand to be looked at with so little on. . . .

column2: Irene strolled round the walls with her.
column3: Irene strolled round the walls with her.

column2: Studies of Lucy, she said.
column3: Studies of Lucy, she said.

column2: I see, dear, said Miss Mapp.
column3: I see, dear, said Miss Mapp.

column2: How clever!	How clever!
column3: true

column2: Legs and things!
column3: Legs and things!

column2: But when you have your bridge-party, won't you perhaps cover some of them up, or turn them to the wall?
column3: But when you have your bridge party, won't you perhaps cover some of them up, or turn them to the wall?

column2: We should all be looking at your pictures instead of attending to our cards.
column3: We should all be looking at your pictures instead of attending to our cards.

column2: And if you were thinking of asking the Padre, you know . . ."
column3: And if you were thinking of asking the Padre, you know . . ."

column2: They were approaching the corner of the room where the screen stood, when a movement there as if Adam had hit it with his elbow made Miss Mapp turn round.
column3: They were approaching the corner of the room where the screen stood, when a movement there as if Adam had hit it with his elbow made Miss Mapp turn round.

column2: The screen fell flat on the ground and within a yard of her stood Mr. Hopkins, the proprietor of the fish- shop just up the street.
column3: The screen fell flat on the ground and within a yard of her stood mr Hopkins, the proprietor of the fish shop just up the street.

column2: Often and often had Miss Mapp had pleasant little conversations with him, with a view to bringing down the price of flounders.
column3: Often and often had Miss Mapp had pleasant little conversations with him, with a view to bringing down the price of flounders.

column2: He had little bathing-drawers on. . . .
column3: He had little bathing drawers on. . . .

column2: Hullo, Hopkins, are you ready, said Irene.
column3: Hullo, Hopkins, are you ready, said Irene.

column2: You know Miss Mapp, don't you?
column3: You know Miss Mapp, don't you?

column2: Miss Mapp had not imagined that Time and Eternity combined could hold so embarrassing a moment.
column3: Miss Mapp had not imagined that Time and Eternity combined could hold so embarrassing a moment.

column2: She did not know where to look, but wherever she looked, it should not be at Hopkins.
column3: She did not know where to look, but wherever she looked, it should not be at Hopkins.

column2: But (wherever she looked) she could not be unaware that Hopkins raised his large bare arm and touched the place where his cap would have been, if he had had one.
column3: But (wherever she looked) she could not be unaware that Hopkins raised his large bare arm and touched the place where his cap would have been, if he had had one.

column2: Good morning, Hopkins, she said.
column3: Good morning, Hopkins, she said.

column2: Well, Irene darling, I must be trotting, and leave you to your-- she hardly knew what to call it-- "to your work."
column3: Well, Irene darling, I must be trotting, and leave you to your- she hardly knew what to call it- "to your work."

column2: She tripped from the room, which seemed to be entirely full of unclothed limbs, and redder than one of Mr. Hopkins's boiled lobsters hurried down the street.
column3: She tripped from the room, which seemed to be entirely full of unclothed limbs, and redder than one of mr Hopkins's boiled lobsters hurried down the street.

column2: She felt that she could never face him again, but would be obliged to go to the establishment in the High Street where Irene dealt, when it was fish she wanted from a fish-shop. . . .
column3: She felt that she could never face him again, but would be obliged to go to the establishment in the High Street where Irene dealt, when it was fish she wanted from a fish shop. . . .

column2: Her head was in a whirl at the brazenness of mankind, especially womankind.
column3: Her head was in a whirl at the brazenness of mankind, especially womankind.

column2: How had Irene started the overtures that led to this?
column3: How had Irene started the overtures that led to this?

column2: Had she just said to Hopkins one morning: "Will you come to my studio and take off all your clothes?" If Irene had not been such a wonderful mimic, she would certainly have felt it her duty to go straight to the Padre, and, pulling down her veil, confide to him the whole sad story.
column3: Had she just said to Hopkins one morning: "Will you come to my studio and take off all your clothes?" If Irene had not been such a wonderful mimic, she would certainly have felt it her duty to go straight to the Padre, and, pulling down her veil, confide to him the whole sad story.

column2: But as that was out of the question, she went into Twemlow's and ordered four pounds of dried apricots.
column3: But as that was out of the question, she went into Twemlow's and ordered four pounds of dried apricots.
